text:
Celebrations, Parades, and Municipal Events: The Russian Squadron during its visit to New York City in the first week of November 1863. It was commanded by Admiral Lessosfky who came with decks cleared for action in case guns could render service to Lincoln and his ideals. His arrival reassured Mayor Opdyke and other Gothamites, as at this time the country was apprehensive of a conflict with England.

This is a set of 2 views; showing in No. 1 the Fleet at anchor in New York Harbor and in No. 2 the armed contingents marching northward past Union Square. Note in the latter, the equestrian statue of Washington, which in this view stands in a circle at Union Square East and 14th Street. In the background of same, and appearing prominently, is the Everett House.

This fleet visited Boston at a later date, for an account of which, see Biography, A p.v. 26; Lessosfky Banquet.

The New York Herald Tribune of October 23, 1937, on page 15, in an article on a new Alaskan stamp issue refers to this naval visit and shows its relationship to our purchase of that territory.

November 1863.

Gift of H. D. Jewett.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Russian Squadron.

text: 14th Street, north side, west from but not including University Place.  About 1880.  New York Edison Company.

Union Square, seen from the S.W. corner at University Place and 14th Street.  Henry K. Browne's statue of Lincoln, erected by popular subscription in 1868, stands in the left foreground, facing away from the camera.  Bartholdi's Lafayette, erected in 1876 by the French residents of the city, is visible in the extreme right of the picture.  Behind it may be seen the old Union Square Hotel on the S.E. corner of Union Square East (Fourth Avenue) and 15th Street, built in the late 1870's.
Union Square, a broad common where Fourth Avenue, the old Bowery Road, and other streets converged, was like Washington Square, once used as a Potter's Field.  In 1845 it was made into a park, and was soon surrounded by fine mansions, remaining the Belgravia of New York up to the time of the Civil War.  At the time of this picture, the fashionable shopping district was located here and north to Madison Square.
On the N.W. corner of Fourth Avenue and 17th Street stands the Everett House, a famous old hotel named after the orator Edward Everett.  Behind it is a 9-story wing very recently added, on the corner of 16th Street; it will later become the Bradley Building, even before the Everett is torn down.  Adjoining the Everett, to the left of the picture, is a new 6-story office building.  The Westmoreland apartment house, on the S.E. corner of 17th Street and Union Square East, is the building in which William Lloyd Garrison died.
Compare this with the same view in January, 1928, New York Edison photo No. 60533

1893
New York Edison Company Collection
title: Manhattan: Union Square - [University Place - 14th Street.]

text:
35-9 Union Square West, between, but not including, 17th and 14th Streets, seen from Fourth Avenue and 17th Street. Preliminary subway construction work is going on in the foreground. October 24, 1900.

PARSONS COLLECTION
title: Manhattan: Union Square (West) - Between 14th and 17th Streets.

Union Square East, north from but not including 14th Street.
About 1902.
Wurts Brothers.
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 14th Street - [George Washington Statue.]

text:
Union Square West, north from East 14th Street, showing the Lincoln statue silhouetted against the buildings that face Union Square. This thoroughfare in reality is a part of Broadway. It’s true identity is lost in that 14th to 17th Street gap that sweeps past the Park. The street cars of the same curved eastward in a serpentine loop forming the well known "Death Curve".

The martyr President stands in the attitude of addressing an audience, and the angularity and ungracefulness of his figure are expressed with painful exactitude. A low curb of granite surrounds the pedestal, and on this are inscribed the famous Gettysburg words, "With malice toward none, With charity for all".

This is the work of Henry K. Browne and was paid for by popular subscription. It was erected in 1868 and complements the nearby equestrian Washington statue.
At the left margin is the 5 story building occupied for years by Tiffany & Company. Opposite is a lower structure with the well known Sol Young, Photographer, as a tenant. These are at East 15th Street. The dominant office building is the 17 story Bank of the Metropolis Bldg., No 31 Union Square West. Broadway reasserts itself in the center background. To the right are buildings that face on the north side of East 17th Street, extending toward Fourth Avenue.

George L. Balgue

February, 1906
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 14th Street (East) - [Lincoln Statue.]

text:
Union Square Park: "The wooden battle ship that never went to Sea" located in the Southern end of the Park, at the head of Broadway. This structure erected during the early days of the World War was used mainly as an enlistment agency. Photographer's vantage point for this set of three views is East 14th Street at Broadway and viewing northward.

1916.

Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.

title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - [S. Klein.]

text:
Classification: Parks

Union Square, seen from the S.W. corner at University Place and 14th Street, nearly identical in scene with the New York Edison Company's photograph No. 49767, taken in 1893. Most of the new buildings shown here were erected between 1902 and 1910. The new Union Square Savings Bank is on the N.E. corner of 15th Street, and the 11-story Reliance Building at 32 Union Square, adjoins the old building now occupied by the Freiheit, a radical Yiddish paper. To the same period belong the Everett Building on the N.W. corner of 17th Street and Fourth Avenue, and the Guardian Life Insurance building (originally Germania Life Insurance) on the N.E. corner. On the street floor of the old Union Square Hotel may be seen one of the signs of S. Klein's dress emporium. In 1930 The Daily Worker, organ of the Communist Party, will be occupying the old building next to the Freiheit, where Elite Styles are shown in this picture; and by 1933 S. Klein will have overflowed into both these buildings. The principal change during these years, however, will be the demolition of the old Westmoreland at 17th Street and of 44 Union Square adjoining, to make room for the new Tammany Hall and Manufacturers Trust Building, and the drastic changes in the park, which in this picture still has much the same general outlines as it had thirty-five years earlier.

January 11, 1928.

New York Edison Company Collection, (No. 60533).
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 14th Street - [Union Square Park.]

1 to 41 Union Square West, west side, north from East 14th (left) to East 17th (right) Streets, showing buildings which line this side of the street, opposite the Park, as seen westward from the Consolidated Edison Co. Building. The vacant lot shown at the S.W. corner of East 16th Street was caused by the demolition of Nos. 21 to 29 Union Square West and 20 and 22 East 16th Street. The horizon formed in the background is the New Jersey Palisades.

March 27, 1929.

New York Edison Company.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (West) - Between 14th and 17th Streets (East).

text:
Union Square East, from 14th to 15th Streets, inclusive, from an elevation, showing the 8-10-12 Union Square, old residences, and the Hotel America at 104 East 15th Street, being remodeled for S. Klein's expending business. This is the newer Hotel America; the building was taken over from the Hotel Jefferson (originally Hotel Dam, built around 1885). The old Union Square Hotel, built in the late 70's, occupies the site of 14-16-18 Union Square, on the S.E. corner of 15th Street. The Union Square Savings Bank on the N.W. corner was erected between 1902 and 1910.
August 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: Communist Demonstration 1937. No's 12-14

View 1 shows girls distributing handbills for a Soviet motion picture; No 2, a tintype photographer in action; No. 3 a boy selling pretzels.

All of these views are taken at Union Square where the photographer is viewing eastward on 14th Street. The clock-tower is atop the Consolidated Edison Co. Building on Irving Place.

May 1, 1937
Views: 1-2-3

P. L. Sperr

text:
14th Street (across foreground), at the S.E. corner of University Place, showing the former Springler Hotel under demolition.  It will be replaced by a 2 story commercial structure.  It is on a part of the old Brevoort farm of 22 acres that Elias Brevoort sold about 1758 to John Smith and whose heirs four years later sold to Henry Springler.  The demolished building was originally a private dwelling and became a hotel after the Springler House of No. 5 Union Square burned down in the 1870's.  It was a favorite rendezvous for actors playing at the old Academy of Music, Tony Pastors, the Union Square and other theaters of the vicinity.  Tradition has it that well known Thespians lived here and that the "Lambs" had their inception here, tho that organization has no record of having formally used these rooms.  A fuller account may be found in the New York Times of June 2, 1938.  Note through the center the extensive view southward on the east side of University Place.

June 15, 1938
F.L. Sperr
